item.title: elotroalex on "Are there essential reads on the open source movement and humanities research?"
item.dc:creator: elotroalex
item.description: Sorry for the delay, this one slipped through the Holiday cracks for some reason. I created the zotero group. Everyone is welcome to chime in and expand the bibliography: https://www.zotero.org/groups/open_source_resources

item.title: elotroalex on "Are there essential reads on the open source movement and humanities research?"
item.dc:creator: elotroalex
item.description: Several months ago, there was an attempt to make a zotero group to gather materials relating to your questions. I just checked now, and there haven't been any entries beyond the original few. Perhaps if we get enough people reading this question to add entries, we can keep a running bibliography of sources. I'm going to create a zotero group that we can all edit and share. Check back later this evening.

item.title: Patrick Murray-John on "Are there essential reads on the open source movement and humanities research?"
item.dc:creator: Patrick Murray-John
item.description:
It doesn't speak directly to research in the humanities, but any list of books about open source needs to have The Cathedral and the Bazaar (from Amazon, too) in it somewhere.

Update: oops, looks like jean beat me to it while I was typing!

item.title: jean_bauer on "Are there essential reads on the open source movement and humanities research?"
item.dc:creator: jean_bauer
item.description:
This might not be what you're looking for, but I think two of the most important (and better written) reads on Open Source are
Eric Raymond's The Cathedral and the Bazaar and Yochai Benkler's "Coase's Penguin". The first looks at the ethos (and genesis) of open source software design and the later is a discussion of the economics of Open Source. Both have been around for a while, and while neither addresses the humanities is particular, I think the parallels are more than apparent.

item.title: tanyaclement on "Are there essential reads on the open source movement and humanities research?"
item.dc:creator: tanyaclement
item.description: I'm looking for articles or books on the affect or use or impact of the open source movement in software development on research in the humanities.
